block.p: Israel Eases Roadblocks And Votes to Free Militants Israel reversed an earlier position and voted to free Islamic militants. It also lifted several roadblocks in the West Bank. The moves came just hours before Prime Minister Ariel Sharon flew to the United States, where he could face rare differences with President Bush on Middle East peacemaking.

U.S. Soldiers Kill 3 Iraqis American soldiers fired on a car in Baghdad, killing at least three Iraqis, as an American Special Operations team prepared to raid a nearby house. The operation involved Task Force 20, which is leading the search for Saddam Hussein.
The Japanese government sought to sell a skeptical public on sending troops to Iraq after winning the bitterly disputed parliamentary vote.
U.S. May Bolster Afghan Aid The Bush administration is weighing a proposal to seek up to $1 billion in aid to help rebuild Afghanistan.

Envoy Appeals to Liberia Rebels Rebel forces pressed forward in Monrovia, Liberia, in their third attempt in two months to take the city as the United States ambassador appealed to the insurgents to lift their eight-day siege and withdraw.

An Almost Peaceful Mutiny No shots were fired and no real threats were made by either side in a mutiny by a band of junior Filipino military officers and troopers that, when it was over, seemed a caricature of the coups and putsches that keep the Philippines on edge.

Voting in Cambodia Elections were held in Cambodia on whether to retain the long-serving prime minister, Hun Sen, as the country seeks to consolidate its recent tradition of democracy. Voting was generally peaceful, except for a small grenade explosion in the capital, Phnom Penh.

Argentines in Custody At least 40 retired Argentine military officials accused of human rights violations during the 1976-1983 dictatorship are now in custody in Argentina and facing trials in Europe after Argentina's new government moved to strip them of their immunity from extradition.

The Recall in California Part Vote, Part Spectacle Interviews around Southern California with Democrats, Republicans and independent voters reinforce what the polls already show: that there is little love for the two-term governor, Gray Davis, who has an approval rate around 20 percent. But that is where the consensus ends and the disorder begins.

U.S. Prison Population Grows The nation's prison population grew 2.6 percent last year, the largest increase since 1999, according to a study by the Justice Department. The jump came despite a small decline in serious crime in 2002.

Working to Prevent Rioting The riots in Los Angeles remain a searing memory for many in Inglewood, Calif. As a verdict nears in the trial of two police officers charged in the videotaped beating of a 16-year-old, about 1,500 so-called peace ambassadors are preparing to fan out into the city to spread the word that violence accomplishes nothing.

Senate May Vote on Emissions Senators John McCain and Joseph I. Lieberman are planning to force a vote on an effort to control global warming when the Senate takes up an energy bill this week. While conceding that their amendment will probably fail, the senators say the debate will help generate pressure on an issue that has prompted much discussion but little legislative action.
Hawaiian Agency Faulted The Hawaii Visitors and Convention Bureau is being reorganized, the latest cloud over an industry that accounts for roughly a quarter of the state's economy.
James P. Shenton A Columbia University history professor who combined serious scholarship with a gregarious command of lecture halls and other public forums, he was 78.
Norman C. Rasmussen A former professor of nuclear engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who pioneered a technique for measuring risk at nuclear power plants, he was 75.

Spiritual Leader Visits Pilgrims in Harlem Sheik Mourtada Mbak√©, the aging spiritual leader of the Mourides, a Sufi Muslim brotherhood that preaches the virtues of hard work and prayer, is in Harlem this week as part of his yearly journey to each of the far-flung Mouride colonies to reinforce those principles that have propelled his flock out of Senegal and across the world.

Councilman to Lie in State Five flags will frame the coffin of Councilman James E. Davis, who was killed at City Hall last week, and whose body will be brought back there when, historians say, he will become the first person to lie in state in City Hall since World War I.
Priest Angers Parishoners An erudite Roman Catholic priest recently assigned to a working-class parish not far from Newark has angered parishioners by imposing aspects of the Latin Mass on services.

Armstrong Wins Fifth Tour Aglow in the yellow jersey of the Tour de France leader, Lance Armstrong rolled into Paris, joining four other riders as five-time winners of the Tour. Mr. Armstrong was joined by the other living five-time winners, from left, Bernard Hinault, Eddy Merckx and Miguel Indurain. Mr. Indurain was the only man to win the Tour de France five times consecutively before Armstrong.

Baseball Immortals Enshrined First baseman Eddie Murray and catcher Gary Carter where enshrined as the newest members of the baseball Hall of Fame. Also honored were Bob Uecker, to the broadcasters wing, and Hal McCoy, who was elected to the writers wing of the Baseball Hall of Fame.

New Charges Against MCI AT&T has evidence that domestic telephone traffic diverted by MCI through Canada to avoid tariffs included calls that were placed by the State Department and other government agencies, a senior executive at AT&T said. The accusation is to be disclosed to government investigators and a bankruptcy court in Manhattan today.

States are Drag on Economy Having already stripped the nation of a source of economic growth, the budget crises in California and in almost every other state are now beginning to drag down the national economy, prolonging the weak, jobless recovery.

Possible Pension Plan Changes Top government officials have begun a calibrated campaign to bring attention to corporate pension plans that, they say, may be on a road to collapse. But underneath their careful words are proposals that could fundamentally change the way pension funds are set aside and invested.

Music Pirates and the Law A blizzard of subpoenas from the recording industry seeking the identities of people suspected of illegally swapping music is provoking fear and professions of remorse as the targets of the anti-piracy dragnet learn that they may be sued for hundreds of thousands of dollars in damages.
